class_notes:
(Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only)


Fake news has become an important part of our daily political culture. Our course will delve into historical hoaxes before turning to the recent past. We will probe political propaganda from 2015 through 2022, including stories of voter fraud, politicians, & international crises. Which societies are more vulnerable to fake news? How can one fight it? Are there clear red flags in our media-saturated world We will work with librarians as we evaluate our evidence.
Each student will develop a case study of an incident of political fake news. 
This course is an Evidence-Focused Seminar: http://evidence.emory.edu/in-the-news/evidence-focused-courses.html. 
Assigned Readings: Online sources & Kate Turabian, A Manual for Writers of Research Papers, Theses, & Dissertations, 9th Ed. (2018) ISBN-10: 022643057X & ISBN-13: 978-0226430577 
Grading Structure: Class discussion, pop quizzes, & lead-in assignments to the final case study.  
Fulfills the following History Concentrations: ¿Law, Economics & Human Rights,¿ ¿United States History¿ & ¿General Studies in History.¿
course_description: Introduces first-year students to the discipline of history, particularly historical sources and methods; aims to improve critical reading, analytical, and writing skills in small group discussion.
schedule_location: T 6pm-8:45pm in New Psyc Bldg 230 (36 Eagle Ro
